awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Influence of the Brood X Cicada Emergence on Soil Water Infiltration
awd_abstract_narration:
In the Spring and Summer of 2021, billions of Brood X cicadas will emerge from the soil, leaving burrows and emergence holes that will potentially affect soil water infiltration rates (the movement of water into soil) and thus surface water and groundwater volumes. The current understanding of how burrowing affects soil water infiltration rates comes from individual locations with localized burrowing, which can limit our understanding of how these biological processes affect large-scale or regional hydrology. By taking water infiltration measurements at many locations in central and southern Indiana with and without cicada emergence holes, this work will advance the understanding of how widespread burrowing can disrupt soil water hydrology. Understanding how this semi-rare cicada emergence (last one was 17 years ago) affects regional hydrology has implications for many environmental science topics such as vegetation water use, river volumes, groundwater table heights, and changes in water quality.  The work will also provide valuable research experience for two undergraduate and two graduate students. Results will be disseminated in manuscripts, conference presentations, news releases, and public data portals. 

In this project, infiltration rates will be measured at multiple locations with and without cicada emergence holes, to improve understanding of how large-scale soil disturbances affect regional hydrology. Using portable infiltrometers in varying landscapes and soils throughout central and southern Indiana, they will measure the influence of cicada emergence holes at two scales: the macropore scale (e.g., one cicada emergence hole) and multi-macropore scale (e.g., many cicada emergence holes).  Results generated from this work will improve understanding of how soil disturbance affects infiltration rates, which has important implications for hydrological processes (e.g., surface runoff, groundwater recharge), water quality (e.g., agricultural leeching), and watershed management.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 2021 emergence of the 17-year Brood X cicadas saw billions of cicadas emerge from the soil throughout the midwestern and eastern United States, leaving soil surface holes and burrows with unknown consequences for local and regional hydrology. Understanding how these burrows affect soil water infiltration rates can help determine whether precipitation enters the soil column or becomes surface runoff and thus gives insight on the fate of groundwater recharge as well as solutes and contaminants on the soil surface. The Brood X emergence in 2021, then, provided a unique opportunity to understand how associated burrowing and widespread emergence can affect soil hydrology. After peak cicada emergence in mid-May to mid-June of 2021, we measured soil water infiltration in terms of saturated hydraulic conductivity (defined as the rate of water flow through soil when the soil is fully saturated) across Bloomington, Indiana, USA, one of the areas where cicadas had a high rate of emergence in 2004 and 2021. Specifically, we measured infiltration rates in areas of little-to-no cicada emergence and in areas of high emergence in two areas: disturbed sites throughout urbanized Bloomington and undisturbed sites in a local forest where soils have experienced little human disturbance. Across undisturbed sites, we found an 80.8% increase in the infiltration rate in soils with cicada burrows compared to soils without cicada burrows. In disturbed sites, we found no significant difference in infiltration rates between sites with and without cicada burrows. Additionally, for undisturbed sites, we found that the number of cicada burrows present at the soil surface was correlated to infiltration rates, while no correlation was found for disturbed sites. Our results, therefore, suggest that cicada burrows result in increased soil water infiltration in undisturbed areas, with negligible changes in disturbed areas. Given that the emergence was widespread and intense across portions of the midwestern and eastern United States, our findings have implications for runoff dynamics, soil and groundwater recharge and quality, and nutrient cycling in other regions.  Data from this project have been uploaded to Consortium of Universities for the Advancement of Hydrologic Sciences, Inc. (CUAHSI) HydroShare. The work has supported the training of multiple undergraduate and graduate students. The measurement techniques have also been incorporated into field-based classes at Indiana University.
